prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator setup is needed to observe multiple transitions of sulphur-bearing molecules. The line width (in the synthetized beam) is expected to be of the order of 2 km/s for all the lines. The spectral resolution (and the number of resolution elements) is needed to resolve the lines and to study the kinematics of the gas.

The requested angular resolution of 0.5 arcsec (equivalent to 70 AU at the distance of the targets) is needed to spatially resolved the line emission and to study the radial distribution of sulphur species in the 2 protoplanetary disks.

The line RMS of 5 mJy is needed to detect the faint molecular emission of sulphur-bearing species in protoplanetary disks. This is a factor of 10 lower than the RMS achieved in the past with PdBI. For the sensitivy estimate we used a bandwidth of 0.3 km/s which is needed to spectrally resolve the emission. With the requested sensitiviy we will reach a S/N > 10 in all spectral channels allowing us to study the velocity profile of the lines.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: One of the major mysteries related to the initial stages of planet formation is the chemical composition of protoplanetary disks. While a dozen of C-, O- and N-bearing molecules have been detected, the sulfur content of disks remains largely unexplored, with only CS and SO being detected. This is in strong contrast with the studies of low- and high-mass star-forming regions where several sulfur-bearing species are routinely observed. We show that SO, SO2, H2S, OCS, CS, and CCS can be employed as uniques probes of the dynamics, grain growth, surface chemistry, and X-ray ionization in protoplanetary disks. Our goal is to perform the first deep study of sulfur chemistry in the two well-known protoplanetary disks. We aim to observe a low-mass TTau star (DM Tau) and an intermediate-mass Herbig Ae star (MWC 480) in SO, SO2, OCS, H2S, CS and CCS in the Band 6 at the 0.5" spatial and 0.3 km/s spectral resolution. The amount of observing time required to detect most of these lines is estimated to be 1.8 hour per source, or 3.6 hours in total.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
